màgnorum munera diuûm sibique veris fa placere dotibus cur mihi non videar fortunatissima tellus digna est mali bona quae parùm novit sua vltima lanigeris animosa est india lucis suis superbus est arab odoribus thuriferis gaudet panchaia dive arenis ibera flumen terra jactat aureum aegypto faciunt animos septem ostia nili laudata rheni vina tollunt accola • laeta nec uberibus sibi displicet africa glebis haec portubus superbit illa mercibus mihi nec fontes nec ditia flumina desunt sulcive pingues prata nec ridentia foeta viris foecunda feris foecunda metallis ne glorier quòd ambiens largas opes porrigit oceanus neu quòd nec amicius ullâ coelum nec aura dulcius spirat plagâ serus occiduas mihi phoebus conditur undas sororque noctes blanda ducit lucidas possem ego laudati contemnere vellera baetis vbi villus albis mollior bidentibus et tua non nequeam miracula temnere memphi verùm illa màjor justiorque gloria quòd latiis quòd sum celebrata britannia grail orbem prodit renovata novis ornata figuris auctior illa tibi notior illa tibi camdeni liber est satis est dixisse scienti camdenum nescis perlege notus erit gvilielmvs sydleivs eques auratur ad amicum suum guil camdenum georgii buc equitis aurati reg sp c heptastichon si quàm describis terram camdene britannam tam graphice tanta curâ gravitate fide que herôum velles britonum re scribere gestas hac etenim sola neglecti parte jacemus historiae poter conferri nulla britannae hoc tibi restat opus vel non hoc fiet aevo secula quòd binos phoenices nulla tulere ad guil camdenum edw grant sacrae theologiae doctor ergóne priscorum lustras monumenta virorum vt possis facili contexere singula filo quae latuere diu caecis immersa tenebris antiquata usu priscum sumptura nitorem vnde britannorum nomen quo coeperit ortu incola quis primus celebres habitaverit oras quavis regione doces quaecunque vetustae sunt urbes quae vera simul comitúm que ducúm que stemma quae terrae dotes quis lime agrorum ordine perspicuo perstringis singula plenè egregium moliris opus vel judice momo quod semper praesens quod postera praedicet aetas te patriae stimulavit amor te docta vetustas excitat ut cunctis patriae spatiêris agris multi multa canunt tu multum scribere tentas hoc multo multos superas qui multa tulerunt tu camdenus eris seros celebrandus annos ergo age quo tendis gressu patriám que venusta ne labor iste tuus desit cupientibus ista antiquam guilielmi camdeni britanniam de te deque tuo libro dum scribere carmen men congesta velit meritas que intexere laudes insonuit mea musa mihi quid carmina quaeris sit scripsisse satis quod scripsit horatius olim hic meret aera liber sosiis hic mare transit et longum noto scriptori prorogat aeuum w gen postremam guilielmi camdeni antiquitatum editionem epigramma g ga sementem sterili quoties tellure recondit luditur optatâ fruge colonus iners ventifugae nunquam dominus ditescit arenae pinguis irriguo flumine terra beat foecundum facunde solum camdene secasti illud ingenii nobile flumen aquat que ut opima solet jacto cum semine gleba parturit innumeris granula adaucta modis sic toties cusus tibi qui fuit antè libellus cultior antiquo prodiit eccè liber heu nusquam tanto respondent arua colono cujus ab ingenio prominet genius sume animum cùm te hinc discedere jusserit aetas vt quaeras tritâ pascua laeta viâ semper camdenus simul que britannia vivent longaeuus nequit hic dum manet illa mori guilielmi camdeni britanniam nescia penè sui generis que oblita prioris anglia cùm jacuit semisepulta situ quis ait tantum aut animis aut arte valebit vindice qui tractet vulnera nostra manu camdenus patriae lugentis imagine motus ingenium artem animos versat opem que tulit mortua restituit veteris cognomen gentis mortis eripuit se patriam que metu aeternùm per te camdene britannia vivit cum que tua aeternùm tu quoque gente mane g carleton ad eundem qvae vix nota sibi fuit antè britannia utri que nunc camdene orbi munere nota tuo est ignotae que velut fuerat non ulla cupido sic modò sic notam mundus uterque cupit sed tamen incassum nimia nam dote superba indignum nullum non sui amoris habet ianus gruterus ic camdeno suo britannia clarus ut eoas sol quando adverberat arces et procul invisis ferit astra liventia flammis nox petit oceanum vultus que enascitur orbi sic camdêne tuum jubar ut fulgere per anglos seu phoebi coepit nox fûgit hispida dudum multum que heu squallens radiare britannia coepi non mea nunc thetis cùm deserit alba profundum gratior exurgit pallentes murice vivo instaurata genas pigro nec sydus ab orco nec dux astrorum de vertice vesper olympi illa ego quàm limâ repolita britannia mirâ fromispicii explicatiomî camdêne tuâ nova nunc magno insula ponto illa ego rupe super scuto horrida horrida gaeso hinc pelagi numen dea spicea visitur illinc piscosus vallo nereus classibus armat que cere flavos spargit sua sertaper agros saxea deinde strues quae depicta videmus fronte libri veluti fervens fontibus unda et surgens pyramis nostrae miracula monstrant telluris liber nequit fa omnia vester exero nunc vultus exhaustos antè ruinis et nunc flore meo marcores pello vietos verùm erit illa dy cùm quae micat anglia forsa • nebula quaeretur cinere occultata situque atque alios lychnos dabit id camdêne negat • historicum vincendo chaos qui noris abundè haec tibi prisca redux tua que u que britannia canto edmundus bolton britanniam denuò illustratam ioh stradlingus insula oceano quondam notissima caecis delituit tenebris vix benè nota sibi ingenii camdene tui radiante tenebras alphabet 〉 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 h cuffius ad guilielmum camdenum britanniam historica veritate denuò illustrantem camdene laus est invidenda praeclarum audire civem patriae que servire autoritati gloriae perenanti camdene dum decus britanniae campu • aeviternae provehis fagax famae nitore regio stiloque praeclaro praeclarus inde civis audis jure quid non decore modò britanniam mactus honore mactus ipse gloriae punctis sed hunc illum luce tua reples mundum vt quae sibi vix nota erat prius terra vtramque nunc domum pulsaverit solis camdene laudis hoc tuae est et extensum quò latiùs volat britanniae nomen camdene augustior tantò tibi sacro adorea memoriae exstabit altari tam nominis cari est litasse regnorum famae inclytasque protulisse virtutes caspar dornavius britanniam redivivam ri parker caiogonvil carmen congratulatorium salve gratae redis memoranda britannia terris quam juvat e tenebris exiliisse tuis fallor antiquo mutatus sistor orbe aut te dum relego secla priora lego fallor arthuros egbertos cassibelinos cerno redivivos ducere castra sua fallor hîc acies saevae certare solebant hîc offa hîc rigidus tendere penda solet festino nimium quae qualia quantum que cerno surgere sacrum deo moenia templa domus quêis hic normannis donari praedia legi vnde sequens soboles nomen omen habet sed quot cerno domus orbatas stirpe vetusta heu quas dilapidant alea vina venus vt vidi ut dolui novus ut nunc sedibus hospes diceret haec mea sunt ito coloni vetus quis genius talem veneranda britannia nobis esse velit reducem quo duce tanta refers scilicet hoc debes camdeno agnoscó parentem et genium cujus te tibi reddit amor foelix ipse suo libro foelicior ipsa praeconem talem laudis habere tuae plus loquar sileam video tantum instar ipso quas musa vocitem sed mea musa sile parcus amor loquitur major stupefactus adegit mirari hoc tacitè nec scio solus opus britanniam à guil camdene illustratam f aderb carmen pictus atrox hebridas glacialem scotus hibernem moverat attacotus vararim saxo que visurgim conjunctis armis animis que excindere gens subruere eximias cumulatis cladibus urbes atque britannorum nomen demergere bellis vt tamen emergant quae sunt immersa ruinis et decus antiquum rediviva britannia cernat ecce vetustatem camdenius eruit omnem magnarum rerum scrutatus magna sepulchra submovit cineres nigrantes dispulit umbra inque prius retrò studiis se contulit aevum contulit atque decus patriaeque sibique labore antiquam camdeni britanniam h n l 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 prisca britannorum delevit nomina tempus antiquas urbes exitioque dedit cuncta triumphato camdenus tempore reddit ingenio priscum restituitque decus ingenio cedat tempus cedatque vetustas ingenium majus tempore robur habet ad eundem errabat quaerens antiqua britannia lumen coasteth upon germanie enforced sore germane sea southward lieth opposite france british disjoyned neighbourcountries convenient distance every way fitted commodious open haven traffique universall world generall good mankind thrusting selfe forward great desire part seasee kent betweene said foreland kent calais france advanceth selfe sea straighted thinke land pierced received sea beforetime beene excluded maintenance conceit alleage virgil verse et penitus toto divisos orbe britannos britans people quite disjoynd world besides britaine saith servius honoratus time past joyned maine also claudian imitation wrote thus —nostra deducta britannia mundo britaine land severed roman world cer • e outward face fashion globe earth hath beene inundation noah flood also cause altered mountaines thereby increased heighth many place higher others setled low became even plaines valley waterie wash dried drie ground turned standing water yea certaine island beene violently broken firme land unto scutula • hlongae long dish bipenni see annotation sir hen savil • knight upon place • citu • two edged axe shapen indeed toward south saith tacitus whereupon fame went whole northward huge enorme tract ground running beyond unto furthermost point groweth narrow sharpe like wedge large exceeding greatnesse circuit olde time tooke beethe panegyricke oration pronounced unto cō stantius untruly entituled unto maximian caesar hee first roman discovered wrote found another world supposing great seemed containe within ocean compassed therewith iulius solinus polyhistor hath left writing largenesse thereof deserveth well neere name second world howbeit age hath length many sundry voyage found sort true dimension compasse whole isle point tarvision unto cape belerium reach crooked regard severall part world well whole saith britaine though want while aspect sunne yet refreshed warmth sea flowing round neither neede marvell speech concerning warmth sea sea quoth cicero stirred regna petunt regit idem spiritus artus orbe alio longae canitis si cognita vitae mors medium est certè populi quos despicit arctos foelices errore suo quos ille timorum maximus haud urget laethi metus inde ruendi inferrum men prona viris animae que capaces mortis ignavum est rediturae parcere vitae yee priest also hight druidae sacrifice leawd barbrous rite forlet war surceasse renewd yee onely joynts world death yee frame precept grounded sure truth knowledge middle point twixt future life went certes northerne people right happie see perswaded vaine conceit wherein nuzzeled feare death men dread stomacks dant maketh resolute bold valiant vpon pike sword runne passe slaine ti cowardise spare life returne againe name soever knowne celt britainesan oke also british welch tongue called derw may seeme name druides came greeke primitive head wit 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 oke held nothing sacred misselto oke whereupon ovid writeth thus adviscum druidae druidae cantare solebant misselto goe druidae goe druidae sing commonly dwelt within okegroves celebrated sacrifice divine service without branch leaf thereof lib 16 cap 4 plinie amply declare word druidae call diviner wisemen estate clergie esteeme nothing world sacred misselto tree whereupon groweth bee oke must take way priest clergie men chuse purpose grove divine service stood onely upon okes nay solemnize sacrifice celebrate sacred ceremony without branch leaf thereof may seeme well enough bee thereupon named dryidae greeke deed whatsoever find growing tree beside owne fruit esteeme gift sent heaven sure signe god others besides hee appointed horseman put sea countrey coast picardy morini third watch fourth houre day arrived upon coast unfit landing place hilles lay steepe sea higher ground dart javelin might easily cast vpon shore beneath therefore one time wind tide hee weighed anchor sailed eight mile place unto plaine open shore hee rid anchor britaines perceiving roman determination sent horse chariot kept roman landing roman exceeding much distressed ship great could ride neere unto shore sea ebbe souldiers strange unknowne place loden heavie armour one instant leape downe necessitie tall ship withall stand amid billowes fight enemy whereas contrariwise britaines perfect knowledge place lightly appointed part body libertie fought either dry shore sure footing wading farre water hereupon roman terrified behaved like courage alacritie time caesar caused gallies remooved hulkes bee rowed laid open side britaines thence enemie beaten backe displaced sling ordinance shot arrowes britans forsake standerd betray enemy hand mine owne part bee sure doe devoir commonweale also generall forthwith hee cast himselfe sea began advance maine standard eagle enemie rest followed hard heeles believe caesaribus julian caesar himselfe first came downe ship fight part eager roman encombred heavie armor weapon tossed wave able get firme footing put array wonderfully troubled untill time caesar caused shipboats pinnace smaller vessel bee manned souldiers saw need helpe sent rescue overcharged soone roman got footing dry land made head together charged britaines put flight able follow chace want horseman arrived island britaines beeing overthrowne battell presently dispatched embassador unto caesar treat peace together foresaid comius arras detained bound prison withall laid fault upon multitude excused owne ignorance caesar soone pardoned commanded hostage delivered unto presently performed part gave word bring rest thus peace concluded foure day caesar landed britaine time eighteene ship transported horseman approching neare coast britanny within view reason suddaine tempest arose cast upon west part island whence much adoe recovered continent france night also hapned moone full tide high gallies drawne shore filled tide ship burden also lay anchor shaken tempest became altogether unserviceable beeing knowne prince britaine understood also roman wanted horseman afresh britans stood still conceived good hope free ever presuming upon small number roman force together scarcitie corne among assembled great power come campe caesar received even campe battell put rout slew many burnt house far neare day came messenger britans caesar intreating peace obtained upon condition double number hostage commanded brought gaule streight autumne september day night equall aequinox hand hee put sea hoised saile britaine brought ship safe unto continent france thither two onely state britaine sent hostage unto rest neglected exploit thus performed upon relation caesar letter senate decreed solemne procession space twentie day although gained nothing himselfe rome glorie onely expedition enterprizeddio lib 39 yeare next ensuing caesar gotten together great fleet ship convoy corne victual private vessel every man built serve owne turne 800 saile manned five legion 2000 horseman launched port calledneere calais iccius landed force part isle hee yeare neither enemie seene place albeit britans beene assembled great power yet terrified huge number ship secretly withdrawne upland countrey caesar encamped place convenient left two cohort three hundred horseman garrison guard ship himselfe night marched forward twelve mile espied enemy gone forward farre river began give battell beaten backe cavallery conveighed wood lay hid lodging place strongly fortified nature man hand roman testudo targnetroofe made mount raised fortification tooke place drave wood neither followed long pursuit fortifie campe place next day caesar divided force three regiment sent pursue britaines straightwaies called back againe hee intelligence messenger tempest sea night navie sore beaten run one another cast shore thereupon himselfe person returned ship labour ten day haled land enclosed campe together within one fortification goeth place whence returned thither also britaines assembled greater force conduct cassivellaunus cassibelinuscassibelinus unto publike counsell britain whole government managing warre committed whose cavallery chariotiers together gave romanes sharpe conflict march wherein many side lost life britans intermission time while roman busie fortifying campe charged fiercely upon kept ward campe unto caesar sent rescue two cohort principall choysest two legion boldly full resolution brake thickest enemy thence retired safety next morrow britans shewed small company hils noone made assault upon three legion horseman sent forage yet beaten backe great number slaine time auxiliarie force met together departed neither encountred afterward roman maine power caesar marched army river thames confines cassivelaunus river thames vpon farther banke river yea water covertly stucke sharpe stake embattelled great power roman went waded violence notwithstanding head cleere water enemy able endure charge left banke betooke flight skared polyaenus writeth sight elephant turret upon backe cassivellaunus courage contend longer retained onely foure thousand charioters observed romanes journey often horseman went foorth straied field forage booty sent chariot kept ranging abroad meane trinobant • trinobantes submit unto caesar intreated would defend mandubratius eutropius beda fragment suetonius lost call androgorius britans androgeus oppression cassivellaunus send unto soveraign caesar required received forty place britans flung back way many flight taken put sword while thing foure pety king ruled kent wit cingetorix carvilius taximagulus segonais mandate cassivellaunus set upon campe romanes navy kept sally romanes made driven backe cingetorix one said king taken prisoner cassivellaunus received many loss troubled revolt state sent embassadour caesar conius ofatrebas arras tending unto surrendry whereupon caesar determined winter continent france commanded pledge brought unto imposed yeerly tribute britaine pay unto people rome withall inhibited cassivellaunus commanded doe harme either mandubratius trinobants thus great number captive embarked army transported backe two severall passage thus much caesar owne warre britain eutropius writing suetonius extant addeth thus much moreover scaeva one caesar souldiers foure fellow servitours crossed sea beforescaeva small barke unto rocke neere iland reflow ebbe ocean left britans many number set upon romanes howbeit rest companion returned ship scaeva tarieth behind still undanted notwithstanding overlaid dart every side first made resistance pike massie speare length tooke sword fought alone many weary wounded withall lost helmet target many stroke two habergeon swum unto caesar campe craved pardon generall fool hardy rashnesse caesar advanced honor degree centurion caesar came first isle cotas one campe second place chariot troubled disordered men able sit sent hee flavus vespasianus afterwards became emperour brother sabinus lieutenant likewise passed river surprised many barbarian slew neither fled rest away morrow joyned battell wherein victorie remained doubtfull untill time c sidius geta point beene taken prisoner enemy vanquished good service triumphall honour granted unto although consull thence barbarian retired river thames dischargeth selfe sea flowe thereof riseth high river soone passed skilfull place would affoord firme footing passable ford roman pursuing danger soone germanes swum second time while passed bridge higher river environing barbarian every side made great slaughter unadvisedly followed rest fell upon blind bog lost many men hereupon britans occasion togodumnus death premenda jugo aspice confundit populos imper via tellus conjunctum est quod adhuc orbis orbis erat britain clime far set thence excluded quite conquerd late washed yet water right britain say far set apart vast sea disjoind walld inaccessible bank craggy clifts behind father nereus fensed billowes invincible ocean likewise compassed eb flowes fallible britain hath wintry clime alotted seat cold northbeare shine alway bright star never set even thy sight first approach ô caesar soone subdud submitted hath necke beare strange yoke servitude behold earth unpassable nation make commixtion heretofore world world conjoined one let tacitus proceed story vntill time went well ostorius soone fortune stood dolefull termes either upon displacing caractacus thereby beene subdued warre ended roman intended carefully militarie service enemy compassion puissant king fervently enflamed revenge environed campmaster legionary cohort left behind build fortress silures country village an fort next adjoyning speedily come rescue beene put sword every man neverthelesse campmaster eight centurion forwardest maniples common souldiers slaine long put flight forragers troupe horseman sent succour ostorius setteth certaine company lightly appointed yet thereby could stay flight legion come undertooke battell strength fought small od either hand afterward wee better enemie betooke himselfe heeles escaped small losse day farre spent many skirmish part manner rodes robbery wood marishes rashly foresight skilled according fell either occasion chance owne heart served one anger another booty sometime commandement captaines sometimes againe without warrant privitie principally wilfull obstinacie silures exasperated speech roman generalls bruted abroad came eares sugambri rooted transported gaul name silures utterly extinguished heat intercepted two auxiliary band avarice praefects forraied spoiled without advised circumspection also large giving away spoiles prisoner drew rest nation revolt ostorius wearied care griefe heart yielded vitall breath whereat enemy rejoyced death captaine despised though died battell yet toiled spent reason warres didius avitus gallus propretor caesar intelligence lieutenant death lest province bee destitute governour appointed didius place beeing thither come great speed yet found good state meane space legion whereof manlius valens charge met unlucky disasterous fight fame whereof enemy made greater terrifie captaine comming also like policie multiplied heard win praise appeasing trouble purchase pardon easily continued still silures wrought u displeasure damage whereupon overran province far nere untill time didius comming driven backe time claudius departed life nero succeeded empire one heart attempt thing warfarenero nay minded withdraw force britain neither gave intent onely shame lest might thought deprave glory claudius caractacus takenvenutius venutius expert man rest military affaire borne state haply brigantes iugantes long time trusty u defended romanes power wife queene cartismandua occasion soone divorce open war rebelled also u proceeded plaine hostility first quarrell onely two untill cartismandua pollicie craft intercepted brother neere kinsman venutius whereupon enemy kindled rage pricked forward ignominous indignity lest brought yoke woman government strong power choise youth force armes invaded kingdome foreseen u thereupon cohort sent aid fought hot battell beginning whereof doubtfull end joifull legion also cesius nasica commanded fought like successe didius yee must thinke strucken yeeres many honour heaped upon thought sufficient execute charge keep enemy ministery others woon others held onely fortress built forward farther country whereby might purchase name enlarging office exploit although atchieved two propraetors ostorius didius many year yet thought good joyne together lest beeing severed well beene remembred didius avicus verannius propretor succeeded verannius small rodes spoiled silures hindered death warring farther man lived carrying great name precise severitie last shewed himselfe manifestly ambitious much flattering nero added would subdued province unto obedience lived next two yeares suetonius paulinus governed britans paulus suetonius propretor one martiall skill opinion people suffereth man without concurrent striving match corbule desirous equall honour recovering armenia subduing enemy stood country therefore hee maketh preparation hee invade isle anglesey mona peopled strong inhabitant receptacle traiterous fugitive purpose hee buildeth flat botom vessel shalowes uncertaine landing place thus footman passed followed horseman foord water thing high swimming put horse enemy stood upon shore diver place embattelled thicke array well appointed men weapon woman also running among blacke mournefull array haire eares carried firebrand hand like fury hell druidae druidae likewise round lifting hand heaven pouring deadly cursing praiers strange unco • th sight amazed souldiers stood still stockes stirred foot would expose body receive wound presented unto afterwards encouraged captaine animating one close open fight batavians began deale blowes lay strike pike buckler mangle face overborne plaine resisted march hill rest cohort gathering heart upon emulation violently beat downe many halfe dead neither forme fight like loose skirmish horseman fro standing still maintaining place sought withall maine weight horse breake beare downe one another wandring waggon also masterlesse horse affrighted feare caried overbare many time met thwarted way britans stood aloofe battell heigth hils good leasure disdained fewnesse began come downe little little wheele back men traine winning field agricola suspecting much opposed foure wing horseman purposely retained sudden dispatch chance war repulsing backe sharply ran fiercely assaile put rout thus counsell britans turned upon owne head wing commandement leader turning quite battell front followed enemy back pursued chase might seen open field grievous pitifull spectacle coursing wounding taking killing taken others offred whole regiment enemy according severall disposition armed though number turned back fewer others unarmed sought death offring voluntarily slaughter every lay scattered weapon body mangled limb ground every embrued arrivall britaine hither part province continued obedience roman civill jurisdiction administration affaire himselfe antoninus went farther part occupied cutting wood making bridge drying mere fought battell howbeit ambuscadoes enemy sicknesse hee lost fiftie thousand men thus writeth dio herodian hath recorded certaine light skirmish while barbarous britaines kept fennie bog thick wood might safely assaile roman upperhand yet enforced end league condition yield unto good part countrey greatest honour ornament empire fensed wall thwart island one coast ocean another victory stamped hee yielded vitall breath yorke uttering point death last word troubled state common weale found every place leave peace quietnesse even among britans body militarie sort carried forth souldiers daulphine braccata gallia province florianus two moneths governed long bloudy battell vanquished probus hanged himselfe whereupon jest went commonly hang tankard man howbeit probus welcommed britaine new trouble commotion one probus emperor zosimus probus himselfe induced commendation familiar friend victorinus maurus promoted office state practised revolt fell way expostulation victorinus gotten leave depart unto said party feining fled escaped emperor kindly entertained tyrant slue night returned probus therewith province rid broiles tyrant man hath related laelianus emperor burgundia • vanda britaine howbeit may seeme cl corn laelianus whose piece coine found island elsewhere moreover probus sent hither burgundians vandal subdued granted place inhabit afterwards often one went raise sedition stood roman good stead whereas vopiscus writeth probus permitted britans vine right learned man feareth lest hee inconsideratly put writing land unfit vineyard yet hath vine certain knowne many regard many tyrant rising day within province hierome carus carinus emperours porphyrie lived age cried termes britaine fertile province tyrant carus augustus emperor allotted decree country together gaule spaine illyricum unto son carinus warred slightly indeed truly wot gather verse nemesianus nec taceam quae nuper bella sub arcto foelici carine manu confeceris ipso pene prior genitore deo neither may war silence hide dispatcht late happy hand north thee carine thy father deifid dost well nere surpasse work worth dioclesian carausius menapian borne man base parentage howbeit inventive active withall valour shewed battels sea became renowned ordained captaine dioclesian maximian emperor bononium galliae bologne gaule put backe drive away saxon frankners troubled sea carausius first time time taken many barbarian prisoner yet neither brought bootie pillage emperor treasury made restitution good unto provincial afterwards hee vanquished subdued began deepely suspected set purpose admitted barbarian enter end passage might intercept booty occasion enrich himselfe whereupon maximian augustus emperour gave commandement killed carausius emperour whereof certaine intelligence tooke upon imperiall ensignes seized britan hand withdrew navy lay defence gaule built many ship roman manner adjoyned himselfe roman legion kept company forreine souldiers assembled drew together french merchant muster fortified bologne garrison conveied away tooke owne use publike revenewes britan batavia allured spoiles whole province small power barbarian force associate frank especially trained seaservice one word made sea coast every way dangerous passage vanquishing maximianus set forward puissant army thebane legion som voyage suffered death gloriously christ sake come seaside skared partly want seasouldiers partly rage british ocean staied made fained peace carausius yielded unto rule island considering taken bee meeter man command also defend inhabitant warlike nation hereupon wee seene silver coines carausius two emperours joyning hand circumscription concordia avg g maximian turned force upon frankners held augusti emperor batavia secretly hand sent aide unto carausius surprized suddennow holland forced submission meane carausius governed britain incorrupt unstained reputation exceeding great peace barbarian writeth ninnius disciple elvodugus hee reedified wall betweene mouthes cluda carunus fortified 7 castle built round house polished stone upon banke river carun tooke name erecting therewith triumphall arch remembrance victory howbeit buchanan thinketh verily temple terminus write scotland dioclesian maximian well keepe recover lost taken constantius chlorus maximianus galerius bee caesar constantius levied enrolled armie came great speed sooner men thought bologne france also called gessoriacum towne carausius fortified strong garrison laid siege unto round pitching log fast earth entry piling huge stone one upon another manner rampire excluded sea tooke towne benefit damme strong violent current ocean beating forcibly many day together could breake beare downe sooner place yielded first tide rose made breach said rampire wholly disjoyned broken sunder panegyrick eumenius while rigged prepared heere elsewhere armada recoverie britaine rid batavia held franck enemy translated many roman nation till waste desert territory meane time allectus familiar friend carausius government state c allectus emperour slew treacherous wile put upon himselfe imperiall purple roabe constantius held seven yeares carausius three allectus whereupon eumenius unto constantius writeth thus brave victorie much importance great consequence yea worthy manifold triumph whereby britaine restored whereby nation frankners utterly destroyed whereby upon many people beside found accessarie wicked conspiracie imposed necessitie obedience allegiance one word whereby assurance perpetuall quietnesse sea scoured cleansed thee ô invincible caesar make thy boast spare thou hast found new world restoring unto roman puissance glorie prowesse sea hast augmented empire element greater land little unto constantius britaine recovered nation also adjoyne unto bound island become obedient pleasure last yeares dioclesian maximian east church beene many year already polluted bloud martyr violence furious porphyrius unto constantine understood omnis ab arctois plaga finibus horrida cauro pacis amat cana comperta perennia jura et tibi fida tuis semper bene militat armis re que gerit virtute tuas populos que feroces propellit cedit que lubens tibi debita rata et tua victores sors accipit hinc tibi fortes te que duce invictae sustollunt signa cohortes northern bound land throughout bleak northwest wind blowen lovs lawes peace right ancient ever knowen prest alwaies loyaltie service thy right valiant couragious heart doth thy battels fight thus nation fierce drive rout doth chase pursue yielding thee right willingly paiments due victor hence valorous thy lot thee unfoiled band advance ensignes brave time evidently appeareth code theodosius pacatianus vicegeren • britaine thirteenth yea • consta • floud hee suddenly seised upon fortune estate many thus went still making spoileammianus marcellinus lib 14 yea undoing great number imprisoning free borne grieving body bond yea bruising manacle patching piecing many crime together laid charge false might whereupon committed wicked act branded day constantius perpetuall note infamie martin vicar britaine one martin ruled province vicar vicegerent grievously lamenting misery calamity innocent beseeching said paulus oftentimes guiltlesse might spared hee saw hee could prevaile threatned depart end malicious inquisitor persecutor leastwise feare thereof might give length enveagle induce open danger men bred nuzzeled quiet peace paulus supposing heereby trade decaied hee vengible fellow linking matter together whereupon came surnamed catena chaine drew said vicar himselfe still maintained defence tendred spared part common peril hee went neere bring also prisoner bound tribune many others emperours privie counsell extremitie mischiefe imminent throughly provoked caught dagger assaulteth paulus right hand failed able give deadly wound hee stabbed himselfe side said weapon drawne foule kind death departed hee pestilent maximinus first deputie lieutenant president notable offence banished britaine impatient rest like noisom beast rose cōmotion theodosius practising mischievous plot insurrection upon certaine swelling pride envie hee perceived alone able withstand horrible designes howbeit casting many meanes secret apert while puffing humour infinite unsatiable desire still encreased solicited well banished person souldiers espied opportunity promising reward allure draw actuall attempt time drew neere enterprizes bee put execution take effect generall advertised project forwarder twaine adventure resolute also upon high mind take revenge attaint convict committed verily valentinus inward complices unto captaine dulcitius bee put death forecasting withall future event hee man militarie skill surpassing others time would suffer farther inquisition examination conspirator feare lest striking terrour among many tempestuous trouble province well appeased might revive againe turning himselfe therefore businesse reforming many enormity necessitie regarded cleared danger evidently seene fortune propitious good unto never forsooke sped enterprizes reedified city garrison fort whereof spake fortified also frontier standing watch strong forefenses thus recovered province yielded subjection enemy hee brought former ancient state upon owne motion valentia areani lawfull governour rule afterward also called valentia prince pleasure areans kind men instituted ancient time concerning related act constans emperor fallen little little unto vice removed station openly quoth scot driven back againe unto fennes bog gratianus emperour saxon consumed battels sea c gratian took upon empire also proclaimed theodosius son theodosius spoken already emperor whereat maximus spaniard borne maximus tyrant zosimus orosius concurrent withall descended right line cōstantinus great also time generall armie britan highly discontented took upon purple roabe orosius reporteth souldiers saluted emperor valiant man vertuous worthy title emperor augustus allegiance way tyranny usurpation attained place first couragiously vanquished picts scot prosper tyro used make many inrodes province afterwards flower strength well neere british force arrived mouth rhene procured unto himselfe whole puissance german army ordained royall seat empire treviris gregorius toronensis day skirmishing forsaken owne souldiers put flight sent saint ambrose embassadour treat peace obtained indeed full treacherous guile cedrenus maximus suborned sent underhand one andragathius riding close litter carroch rumour spread abroad therein rode wife gratian unto gratian come love wife opened said litter forth leapes andragathius companie slew outright place whose body demand ambrose sent sonne sulpitius alexander custodie gaule gave frankners annoied gaule incursion mightie great overthrow forced give hostage deliver hand author warre valentinian earnestly besought theodosius succour dispoiled empire tyrant good could none answer zonaras marvel seditious servant became superiour lord casteth true lord indeed valentinian corrupted arianisme howbeit wearied length importunate praiers setteth forward warlike manner maximus time abode aquileia secure fearlesse beforehand fortified streits mountain garrison haven shipping great alacritie much confidence first hee welcomed theodosius one battel syscia pannonia zosimus afterwards valiantly received another sisseg leading brother marcellus sped badly withdrew himselfe secretly aquileia owne souldiers dealt money among taken devested imperiall ornament brought theodosius immediatly delivered hangman hand executed worne purple roabe five yeares whereupon ausonius writeth thus praise aquileia non erat iste locus meritò tamen aucta recenti nona inter claras aquileia cieberis urbes itala ad illyricos objecta colonia monte moenibus portu celeberrima sed magi illud eminet extremo quòd te sub tempore legit solverat exacto cui justa piacula lustro maximus armigeri quondam sub nomine lixae foelix qui tanti spectatrix laeta triumphi • udisti▪ punîsti ansonio rutupinum marte latronem place name since fresh desert gave grace thou aquileia city faire shalt ninth place colonie italian gainst hils illyrian set strong wals commodious right well renownd yet passeth rest choice thee make latter day revengement justly take maximus base campesquire sometimes knowne usurped five yeares past ruled tyrannie right happy thou triumph hadst joyfull sight killing robber british britaine rhutupine maine italian might andragathus whose state desperate cast himselfe shipboard headlong sea victor sonne maximus france defeated taken prisoner slaine britans tooke part maximus writer doe record forcibly invaded armorica france planted theodosius presently victorie entred rome sonne honorius triumph published edict effect man hardy challenge claime honour bold tyrant granted presumption bee condemned reduced former estate valentinian word judgement award whatsoever maximus wicked detestable tyrant ever hath given forth promulged enacted reverse condemne saint ambrose funerall sermon theodosius crieth termes eugenius maximus wofull example doe testifie hell heavie thing beare armes naturall prince speake word victory held worthy memorable roman thence forward procopius solemnized day every yeare festivall succeeded theodosius west empire sonne honoriushonorius emperour child ten yeares old ordained tutor protector flavius stilicho man passing famous long time inward companion theodosius warres victory degree militarie service advanced unto high authoritie prince affinitie end cloied glutted prosperitie carried away ambition miserably lost life man surely certaine yeares provident regard empire good estate defended britaine invasion picts scot vandal hereof britaine speaketh thus selfe claudian quo que vicinis pereuntem gentibus inquit munivit stilicho totam quum scotus hibernem movit infesto spumavit remige thetis illius effectum curis ne bella timorem scotica nec pictum tremerem ne littore toto prospicerem dubiis venientem saxona ventis likewise hand quoth perish despight neighbour nation stilicho protected gainst might time scot ireland movd offensive armes take stroke enemy ore sea much fome make brought passe care scotish warre feare dread picts ne yet ken farre along shore while looke still wavering wind turne saxon comming saile coast spoile burne thus time britaine seemed safe enough danger enemy another place poet writeth thus —domito quod saxona thetis mitior aut fracto secura britannia picto either sea quiet saxon conquerd britaine become secure since picts subdued alaricus king gothes hovered rome seeking meanes assault spoile legion march kept station barbarian called hence claudian signifieth reckoneth aid sent part venit extremis legio praetenta britannis quae scoto dat fraena truci ferro que notatas perlegit exangues exanimes picto moriente figuras legion also came british frontier lie garrison curb fell scot doth pursue eie yronbrent markes picts seene bloudlesse die fastidius genadius chrysanthus niephorus day flourished fastidius bishop britaine wrote bookes divine learning assure chrysanth • likewise sonne bishop martian beene consular deputy italy theodosius made lieutenant deputie uicar britan deserved praise admiration home utter disclaiming renouncing return confidently usuall manner beene seize hand northern utmost part land hold naturall inborne inhabitant even far wall attempt opposed placed upon high fort castle along wall garrison nothing warlike unfit fight quaking heart altogether unmeet service warding day night became lazie nothing meane stay bare naked enemy approached fort wall hooked weapon engine wherewith miserable people plucked walles dashed hard ground good yet manner hasting untimely death unto meanes speedily rid world quick dispatch escaped avoided wofull imminent calamity brother deare child bee short abandoned city quit highwall againe tooke flight dispersed anew desperate manner time semblably enemy follow hard chase hasten make fouler havocke cruell butcherie like therefore lamb bloudy butcher wofull inhabitant quartred mangled enemy insomuch abode among might well compared ravening wild savage beast poore wretched people forbeare rob one another short sustenance small food also hostile outward misery calamity augmented inward tumult trouble like pillage spoiles practised thicke whole country exhaust victual staffe strength life save onely small comfort came hunting copy agitivs equitius co without number whereupon distressed remaines send missive letter againe unto aetius powerable man roman state tune aetivs thrice consvll grones britans barbarian drive u backe sea sea againe putteth u backe upon barbarian thus betweene tweene two kind death either throat cut drowned yet obtaine succour distress meane wandring declining condition notorious horrible famine oppresseth forced many without delay yield hand cruell spoiler robber might food never little comfort refresh poore hungry soules others never wrought much chose rather withstand rise continually mountaines cave thick wood full bush brier bramble verily first gave sundry overthrowes much slaughter enemy many yeares together made spoile drave away booty land reposing trust man god according saying philo helpe god hand man helpe faileth thus rested enemy boldnesse yet countryman gave wickednesse enemy say retired people people retire wickednesse usuall manner ever nation like day also shew feeble repressing enemy force strong enough civill warres undergoe burden sinne c well shamelesse irish ravenours returne home minding shortly make repaire hither againe picts rested without molestation first thenceforth utmost part province yet without wasting harrying country sundry time meanes therefore surcease hostility desolate people sore famin healed clean skinned another virulent secretly bred brake forth time island free hostile wasting happened fruitfull plenty abundance thing like age ever remembred therewith groweth evermore manner riot excesse mightily encreased came great head fitly time might said certainely hard fornication like among gentile sinne onely rife others also incident man nature especially likewise day overturneth state goodnesse hatred truth maintainer thereof love also lie forger thereof admitting evill good respective regard leawdnesse stead goodnesse desire darkenesse lieu sunlight accepting satan angell light king anointed king annointed god knowne cruell rest soone murdered owne anointer without due examination truth others fierce cruell elected one king seemed mild somewhat better inclined truth upon subverter britaine hatred spitefull dart men without respect levelled shot difference made thing tooke displeasure thing weighed equall ballance saving better thing indeed wrought ever discontent much right justly saying prophet denounced unto people old time might bee applied unto country yee lawlesse corrupt child forsaken lord provoked unto wrath holy one israel ye smitten still multiplying iniquitie every head sicke every heart heavy sole foot unto crowne head nothing sound therein thus thing contrary safetie phisicke medicine bestowed upon world true phisician onely secular lay men also selected flocke lord shepheards thereof ought given example whole people speake drunkennesse number drenched wine lay benummed senselesse possessed swelling pride therewith stomackfull given attentive eares men giving notice ancient enemy ready arrive upon comming fully minded destroy utterly wonted manner possesse inhabite countrey one end another yet never better like unto foolish senselesse horse resisting bridle reason refusing admit bit say close shut mouth leaving way salvation narrow though ran downe randum broad way wickednesse leadeth directly readily death while etymologie scotish nation like neighbour nation round full obscuritie lie overspred mist darkenesse sort even buchanan himselfe though otherwise man deepe insight either hath seene little therein seene himselfe alone point hath come short men expectation whereupon forborne long time take enterprize hand lest others admiring fable full sweetly please selfe fall folly man may great probability proved passed britan time first known unto writer name seated ireland claudian poet hath written irruption britaine verse —totam cum scotus hibernem movit infesto spumavit remige thetis time scot ireland stird offensive armes take maine stroke enemy ore sea much fome make also another place scotorum cumulos flevit glacialis hiberne frozen ireland heapes scot bewaild many teare orosius likewise writeth thus ireland peopled scotish nation gildas calleth scot irish spoiler beda scot inhabite ireland isle next unto britaine also elsewhere yea day charles great eginhardus expresse word calleth ireland isle scot moreover giraldus cambrensis scottish nation saith descended ireland affinitie well language apparell weapon also manner even day doe sufficiently prove come unto point would scot throughly weigh much right naturall scot acknowledge name scotsgaiothel gaithel g • el otherwise call gaoithel gael albin seeing also many people name given unto neighbour use whereby often time frisones name iland britones seeme great multitude people every yeere mightie number wife child flit thence unto frank give entertainment part land seemeth desert rest hereupon men say challenge unto verie iland verily long since king frank sent certaine people embassage constantinople unto emperour iustinian sent withall english pretending ambitiously iland dominion people germanie planted writeth went lightly appointed garment reaching mid knee head shorne beard shaven upper lip uncut mustache grew continually wearing massie bracelet gold armes carrying markes upon skin pounced sundry commonly kenet kenet river ariseth neere unto little village name would cvnetio mentioned antoninus distance side gainsaieth heere selburie round hill mounteth aloft great height forme hill selfe outward settling earth beneath may seeme beene cast man hand many sort round sharpe top bee seene tract burrowes call barrowes barrowes burrow tombes raised happily memoriall souldiers slaine bone found read usuall thing northerne nation every souldier remaining alive foughten field carry headpiece full earth toward making fellowes tombes slaine although opinion rather selburie set stead limit roman certainly saxon like fosse called wodensdike considering betweene mercians westsaxons much bickering shire many timein geomeotrie march 198 boetius aibury grammaticall writer made mention mount raised bound within one mile selburie aiburie uplandish village built old campe seemeth large compasse environed faire trench hath foure gappes gate two stand huge stone jambes rude seeme rather naturall artificiall sort said village river kenet runneth first eastward certaine open field stand aloft every stone like rockesrockley little village called rockley among breaketh sometimes unawares water manner streame sudden landflood reputed messenger forerunner dearth rusticall people countrey called hungerborne hence famis rivulus kenet holdeth course towne bearing name called antoninus cvnetio placed verlucio twenty mile distance thence ancient towne called new name marleborow old time marleberge standeth upon river kenet cunetio towne marleborow cunetio kenet stretching east west pendant hill whether name marleborow came latter age marga language call marle use stead dung manure ground ready affirme certes lieth neere chaulkey hill ancestours borrowed name chaulke latine word segont ninnius gervase canterburie witnesse constantine putting sea britaine landed atbononia bologne france drew roman army even farre alpes side joyne warres hee stoutly defended valentia france power honorius emperour river rhene long beene neglected hee fortified garrison upon alpes passage hee built fortress spaine conduct sonne constans monke declared emperour warred fortunately afterwards sent letter unto honorius craved pardon suffering souldiers put upon purple perforce whether hee would accepted hand imperiall investure hee freely gave whereupon puffed pride hee passed alpes mind wholly set upon journey rome hearing alaricus gothe favoured part dead hee returned arles hee setled imperiall seat caused citie bee called constantina commanded court assembly seven province bee holden meane time gerontius excited souldiers lord treacherously slaine sonne constans vienna france besieged constantine also himselfe within arles one constantius sent honorius great armie made head gerontius killed himselfe constantine streitly besieged reason unhappie successe men past hope laid aside purple great estate entred church became priest straightwaies arles yeilded old time royall mansion english saxon king also noble ethelwald held legacie uncle father side king hath thereby decaying house farre river seene broken walles old large castle midst towne church west end whereof made arched worke embowed head seemeth bee ancienthaga heere bee seene william first booke king seventy five hages house wherein remained one hundred seventy five men nothing famous treacherie crueltie goodwin earle kent yeare christ 1036 elfrid king etheldreds son heire apparent crowne england came normandie claime right entertained faithfull promise safety forthwith hardly entreated contrary worddecimation sodainly dead night hee surprised put death place sixe hundred norman accompanied young prince tithing writer report neither slew hee every tenth man drawne lot according old militarie custome even hee killed nine let tenth man goe even tenth men thus reserved hee went againe cruelly retithed elfred himselfe hee delivered hand harold dane hee pulled eies head overlayed iron kept close prison even unto dying day wey beeing passed hence long course northwardoking woking sheweth nothing memorable besides sutton residence weston ancient family knight degree caesar passed tamis border cassivelannus forwhere cae • crossed tamis onely place man might time past goe tamis foote hardly britaines improvidently bewraied unto caesar side river great power commodious enough iron maisters cast much great ordnance thereof thing small gaine whether bee gainefull profitable commonwealth may bee doubted age ensuing bee better able tell neither want whose commendation certaine english man unlearned age wrote unlearned verse anglorum reginatuos adeliza decores ipsa referre parans musa stupore riget quid diadema tibi pulcherrima quid tibi gemma pretious stone dimne diademe thee gemne hath beautie none away trimme gay attire nature attireth thee thy lovely beautie naturall never bettred ornament beware favour thou dost take thee lustre thou calais narrow sea two head promontory narrowsea strait calais frenchman pa de callais place saith poet time —gemini quà janua ponti faucibus angustis latèque frementibus undis gallorum anglorumque vetat concurrere terras current two sea gullet streight wherein throughout billowes rage fret keepes france england part though never met narrow sea marcellinus truly writeth swelleth every tide terrible high flouds againe ebbe becommeth flat plaine field raised wind counter sea betweene two rising moone floweth twice ebbeth oft moone ascendeth toward meridian set againe horizon opposite point ocean heere swelleth mightily huge billowes rush upon shore great noise poet might well say rhutupiná que littora fervent rhutup shore doth boile billow paulinus speaketh county bulloigne termeth utmost skirt world without cause used word oceanum barbaris fluctibus frementem ocean raging roaring barbarous billowes heere might arise question beseeming learned man hath wit time willwhether britanie time past joyned unto france whether narrow sea runneth france britaine narrow banke necke land time past conjoyned region afterwards broken either generall deluge rushing wave else occasion earthquake let water make passage verily man make doubt face whole earth hath beene altered partly said deluge partly long continuance time cause also ilands earthquake shrinking back water laid joyned unto firme land certainly appeareth author best credite ilands reason earthquake breaking water severed disjoyned rent continent whereupon pythagoras ovid saith thus vidi ego quod quondam fuerat solidissima tellus esse fretum vidi factas ex aequore terras selfe seene maine ground sometime turned sea sand seene againe sea became maine setled land strabo gathering thing come past concluded isthmus neckes narrow bankes land beene shall bee wrought pierced see saith seneca whole region violently removed place lie beyond sea lay bounding upon hard see separation made country nation part nature provoked selfe mighty wind beateth strongly upon sea force whereof generall wonderfull although rage part yet universall power rageth thus hath sea rent spaine continent africke thus deucalions floud much spoken greatest poet sicilie italy hereupon virgil wrote thus haec loca vi quondam vasta convulsa ruinâ tantum aevi longinqua valet mutare vetustas dissiluisse ferunt cùm protinùs utraque tellus vna foret venit medio vi pontus undis hesperium siculo latus abscidit arva que urbes littore diductas angusto interluit aestu land whilom violence breach ruines great change make time long time doth eate sunder fell men say one grow sea brake force mids overthrow townes ground italy forthwith sicily side cut inlet streight doth still part divide plinie sheweth likewise isle cyprus rent syria eubaea baeotia besbicus bythinia part maine land none old writer ever able avouch britaine severed maine onely verse virgil claudian cited first entrance worke together conjecture servius honoratus doe insinuate much yet dominicus marius niger master iohn twin right learned man whosoever wrested verse made scicilia unto britaine opinion —britannia quondam gallorum par una fuit sed pontus aestus mutavere situm rupit confinia nereus victor abscissos interluit aequore monte —some time britannie part france swelling tide hie changed site nereus conquerour hath torne confines quite runnes betweene cliff sounder worne considering therefore matter assured ground upon certaine authoritie learned laying comparing like example narrow sea searching truth propose like point duly weighed considered first whether nature soyle shore verily found even shore either side distance betweene narrowest riseth loftie cliffes matter colour may seeme beene riven asunder secondly great breadth sea streight certes streight heere much broader either streight gibraltar scicily wit twenty foure mile first sight one would imagine land severed billowes raging counterseas vultumque diones pestanae non labra rosae non lumen gemma lilia non aequant crines non colla pruinae vtque fluit crines madidos terga repellit reddit undanti legem formamque capillo en subitò frontem placidis è fluctibus isi effert totis radio spargentia campis aurea stillanti resplendent lumen vultu iungit optatae nunc oscula plurima tamae mutuáque explicitis innectunt colla lacertis oscula mille sonant connexu brachium pallent labra ligant animos tandem descenditur unà thalamum quo juncta fide concordia sanctum splendida conceptis sancit connubia verbis vndíque multifori strepitat nunc tibia buxi flucticolae nymphae dryad satyríque petulci numeros circùm ludunt ducuntque chorea dum pede concutiunt alterno gramina laeti permulcent volucres sylva modulamine passim certatímque sonat laetùm reparabilis echo omnia nunc rident campi laetantur amores fraenatis plaudunt avibus per inania vecti personat cythara quicquid vidêre priores pronuba victura lauro velata britôna haec canit ut toto diducta britannia mundo cùm victor rupes divulserit aequore nereus et cur neptuni lapidosa grandine natum albionem vicit nostras delatus oras hercules illimes libatus thamisis undas quas huc adveniens ar sacravit vlysses vtque corinaeo brutus comitatus achate occiduos adiit tractus ut caesar anhelus territa quaesitis ostendit terga britannis c verse dixerat unito consurgit unus amore laetior exultans nunc nomine tamisis uno oceanúmque patrem quaerens jactantior undas promovet heere zephyrus fresh greene grasse bankes doth spread flora faire flora ayliving herb adourneth isi head lovely doth move shee leavs tame town knowen name haile fare well redoubling norris old dorchester length shee see give presage lucky augury long wished marriage riseth tame know lock eares corn full well knit kirtle green wast eke adorn lightsome ray morning bright doth far excell dione faire countenance lookes halfe well lip pestane rose surpasse eye gemmes great cost haire lily fresh white necke hoary frost runnes haire wet doth behind cast waving thus kembeth slick layeth even last lo isi sudainly wave mild doth shew lovely face eies withall glitter golden hew dropping visage send beames field throughout while one anothers neck armes displayd clip full sweetly doth tama kisse hath wishd long thousand kiss twixt twain doe resound among clasping close armes wax pale lip heart linke fast nuptiall chamber thus jointly descend last concord religious faith together ymet knit knot wedlock sure word forme yset pipe thyrled box every side resound water nymphes dryad wanton satyr round place disport dance measure cunningly while grasse foote fine round merily bird heerewith every wood melodiously doe sing echo redoubled note mirth strives forth ring thing laugh field rejoice cvpids fly amid aire bridled bird clap hand right pleasantly britona handfastmaker shee clad laurell green play harp ever act auncestours seene shee sings britanny world divided nereus victorious sea cloven rock variety ware merchandize sort citty adjoyning chiefly love chiefe apostle reverenced speciall singular affection made choise place owne sepulchre thereupon commanded tenth rent worke noble edifice bee caesar city drusomagus city drusus also seeme beene built honour caesar augustus suaetonius writeth thus king amity league founded every one owne kingdome city named caesareae honour augustus say caesaromagus stand neere unto brentwood would learned reader laugh one soothsayer doth spieth another certes ground reason strengthen conjecture distance thereof seeing number mile antonine corruptly put downe neverthelesse agree well enough distance colonia canonium neither helpe selfe proofe situation upon roman highway enclosed country seene neither verily remaineth heere much shadow twinkling shew name caesaromagus unlesse sclender name hundred old time called ceasford cheasford hundred surely ancient city name little altered others cleane changed againe wherein one syllable twaine bee remaining thus caesaraugusta spaine altered saragosa caesaromagus france hath lost name cleane called beavois caesarea normandy cherburg hath one syllable left meane thus trifle dwell point quarter farre sea fenne william monke crowland life guthlake hath thus described verse est apud angligenas à grontae flumine longo orbe per anfractus stagnosos fluviales circumfusapalus orientalisque england lie gront river side among winding crankes lake river far wide spred neere unto bankes easterne sea doth stretch selfe southerne side along north eastward reach muddy gulfe unwholsome fish breed reed doe shake growing thicke wind word whispering noise make joyne hereunto please thus much henry huntingdon fenny country saith passing rich plenteous yea beautifull behold watered many river running downe garnished number mere great small trimly adorned likewise many wood ilands small conclusion matter take also word william malmesbury speaking time great store fish stranger comming hither make wonder inhabitant laugh thereat see wonder neither waterfoule lesse cheape one halfe penny five men least may onely eat slake hunger content nature also feed fill fish foule touching drying fenny country discourse arguing oftentimes hath beene either way sound wholsome counsell goodly pretence shew common good even high court parliament list relate pausanias corinth feared least often hath happened pontine marishes italy would come againe former state many thinke wisest best course according sage admonition like case apollo oracle intermeddle god hath ordained upon naturall strength place plenty thing seditious rebel often presumed onely english banded william conquerour baron also whensoever outlawed hence troubled molested king evermore ill successe albeit otherwhiles third lindsey holland ingulph termeth holland lyeth sea like unto holland germanie throughly wet place water man foote ready sinke one standeth upon ground shake quake foot thence may seeme taken name townes entry thereinto upon river welland standeth stanford stanford saxon tongue 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 built rough stone whence hath name towne well peopled great resort endowed also sundry immunity recordeth hee built strong castle towne also south banke called stanford baron yet appeareth one token thereof day forsee burghley county northampton castle time civill warre stephen strengthened henry anjou within towne generall report holdeth plot also whereon stood yet remaining sheweth soone said henry king england gave whole towne stanford demaine excepting fee feifs baron knight towne unto richard de humez homets constable king soveraigne lord homage service afterwards held william earle warren pleasure king john raigne edward thirdan academy university begun stanford university publique profession good learning beganne heere inhabitant count small credit unto hote debate contention betweene northren southren student oxford great number scholers withdrew hither small returned upon king proclamation oxford sodainely beganne ended soone new university thenceforward provided oth student oxford publiquely professe reade stanford prejudice oxford neverthelesse flourished fresh trading merchandise untill civill warre betweene two house lancaster yorke grew hore northren souldiers breaking towne destroyed fire sword neither could ever since time fully recover ancient dignity yet good estate civill government thereof consisteth alderman foure twenty burgess brother beautified seven parish church thereabout sheweth old hospitall faire house founded william browne burgesse besides another new one side bridge lately built nestor britaine sir william cecill baron burghley time hee raised stately sumptuous house burghley whereof spoken already northamptonshire lieth enterred goodly gorgeous tombe within parish church saint george man say nothing else course nature owne glory lived long enough regard country died oversoone although token remaining antiquity commonly called highdike highstreet made roman soone without towne leadeth direct way north may sufficiently shew sometimes ferry waterfare heeregausennae yet towne gausennae antonine emperour placeth shifted many time breaking day still made default end mortgaged unto king three castle namely hay brecknock radnor put hand soone levying certaine force could muster haste upon suddaine surprised slew garison souldiers wrested said peeces perforce burnt towne lemster thus killing slaying driving away booty made foule worke havocke every way outrage rebel doe commonly commit king pursued hee conveyed himselfe ireland complotted combined king enemy yet colour hee would make submission hee came unto king upon protection assurance given safety upon returne ireland notwithstanding many goodly noise roaring loud severn nymph doth cry newtowne thee bearing spite unto ground thereby cast sends violence maine drift hurtfull sand neighbour part feele equall losse heavie hand thy little well lay weight would woo faine embrace virgin along shore doth goe calld though lurkes den striveth hard againe ebbe flow continually tide keepe twaine yet diversly nymph doth rise spring doth fall goe backe stopping passage veines spring keepeth water contrariwise surface thereof voide empty water veines source spring unstopped set free water boileth great abundance hence coasting along shore come within leicester partly money gathered many well disposed throughout england said robert yeere 1564 created queene elizabeth baron deubigh heires body lawfully begotten neither one barony england hath gentleman holding thereof fee service diffrin cluidnow come heart shire nature removed hils way side shew could doe rough country hath spred beneath beautifull pleasant vale reaching 17 mile length large faire castle able receive entertaine great houshold towne reginald grey king edward first granted roger grey built obtained licence king bishop saint asaph parson church lhanruth whose parish place sited unto recompense part good service performed welsh king edward first given manner whole vale seat heires men great honour length stiled title earle kent untill richard grey earle kent lord ruthin issue care brother henry passed away summe money ancient inheritance unto king henry seventh late day bounteous magnificence queene elizabeth bestowed upon ambrose dudley earle warwicke together rich revenewes vale ascend vale eastward come yale little hilly country comparison region beneath round passing high river elsewhere commeth sendeth forth reason high situation bleake exposed windes side whether tooke name riveret alen rising first undermineth ground twice hideth himselfe know mountaines full neat sheepe goates vallies plenteous enough corne especially east side alen upon city selfe setting fire afresh william malmesbury saith hee depopulated defaced village adjoyning sinewes fertile region cut spoiles committed booty raised ground space threescore mile lay gagates old time held one rare gem precious stone groweth among cliffes rockes chinke gape asunder polished reddish rusty colour bee polished becommeth saith solinus aothers opinion pit cole • stone cole wa • old gagates gemme bright radiant blacke colour touching rhemnius palamon dionysius afer thus versifieth praefulget nigro splendore gagates hic lapis ardescens austro perfus • aquarum ast oleo perdens flammas mirabile visu attritus rapit hic teneras seu succina fr • ndes geat blacke shineth passing bright stone water dipt drencht take fire burneth light oile wonder see flame quickly done like amber rub hard small stickes catcheth soone marbodaeus little booke precious stone nascitur lycia lapis prope gemma gagates sed genus eximium foecunda britannia mittit lucidus niger est levi lavissimu • idem vicinas paleas trabit attritu calefactus ardet aqua lotus restinguitur unctus olivo geat stone gemme well nere men lycia finde fruitfull britan yeelds best simply kinde colour blacke yet bright smoothe light withall well rubbed enchauld thereby thin strawes fescue small neere hand drawes thereto burnes water drencht annoint fatty oile flame streigthwaies quencht heare also solinus saith britaine great store gagates geat excellent stone demand colour bright radiant blacke quality manner nothing weighty nature burneth water quenched oile vertue made hote rubbing holdeth thing applied thereto whitby shore give backe westwardcliveland lyeth cliveland taking name seemeth steepe bankes language wee call cliffes runne along side thereof cliffie hilles foote country spreadeth plaine full fertile field upon shore sken grave little village much benefited taking great store fish also report caught seaman 70 yeeres since certaine day together fed raw fish espying opportunity escaped away unto proper element againe whensoever windes laied upon still weather sea calme water lieth one would say levell plaine without noise heard heere many time sudden great way horrible fearefull groning time fisherman dare launch farre deepe beleeving according shallow reach ocean fell cruell beast hungry desireth greedily sort devoure men body beneath skengrave situate kilton castle within parke belonged sometime habitation thwengs whose patrimony descended baron lumley hilton daubeneie joyneth almost close unto skelton castle appertaining ancient family baron brus brius skelton derive descent robert brus norman said robert two sonnes adam lord skelton robert anandale scotland descended royall stem scotland peter brus fifth lord skelton died without issue left sister inherite namely agnes wife walter falconberg lucie baron falconberg wedded marmaduke thweng come baron lumley margaret married robert ro laderina john belleeau men age honourable reputation heires successively walter falconberg flourished long time end female possession came sir william nevill redoubted knight martiall prowesse king edward fourth advanced title earle kent daughter bestowed marriage upon sir john cogniers n bedhowing r strangwaies neere unto huntcliffe farre shore appeare aloft vale water certaine rockes fish wee call seales short thinke seaveales meete together drove sleepe sunne upon rocke next unto shore lieth one keepe centinell man approcheth neere either throwing downe big stone tumbling himselfe water great noise giveth signall rest looke unto get water affraid bee men chase destitute water fling backeward hinder feete cloud sand gravell stone yea often time drive away woman care much therefore whosoever would take use bee clad woman apparell coast found stone yellowish others reddish colour againe rough cast crust certaine salt matter smell taste make shew coperose nitre brimstone also great store marquesites colour resembling brasse hard luguballia • 5 mile round time also walled strong citizen saith bede brought cuthbert see wall city fountain well built time past according wonderfull workmanship romanes time saith book durham greenish water hath river communicateth name vale hee runneth called douglasdale also douglasse castle therein name castle likewise hath imparted unto family douglass assure ancient famous ever since enterred earles strathern fine 35 h 3 n 1the first earle strathern read malisse time king henrie third england married one heires robert muschamp potent baron england long afterward robert stewart christian name enjoieth also dignity realmes one king privie councell buchania buquhan taizali mentioned ptolomee ancient time inhabited buquhan latin boghania buchania river done beareth forth toward german sea derive latter name bobus ox kine whereas notwithstanding ground serveth better feed sheepe whose woole highly commended albeit river coast everie breed great store salmonsriver ratra yet doe never enter river ratra buchanan hath recorded neither let offensive cite testimonie although bookes authoritie parliament yeere 1584 forbidden many thing contained dashed admirable water also hath written banke ratra cave neere unto stangs castle nature whereof seemeth passed water distilling drop naturall vault presently turneth pyramidall stone said cave hole otherwhiles rid cleansed man labour whole space far vault would short time filled therewith stone thus engendred middle nature betweene yee hard stone brittle easie crumble neither groweth ever soliditie hardnesse marble claikgeese concerning claikgeese much admiration beleeved grow tree upon shore elsewhere ripe fall downe sea scarce worth labour mention little bird engendred old rotten keeles ship beare witnesse saw ship wherein francis drake sailed world standing docke neere tamis outside keele whereof number little bird without life feather stuck close yet would gladly thinke generation bird logges wood ocean lodgeth hee hath watered rothes castle whence family lesleys tooke title earle ever since k james second conferred honour earle rothes upon sir george lesley concerning spey poet necham hath thus englishman borne hurt state irishman constable defended badly also certaine connivencie suffered prisoner make escape touching hearken giraldus saith tearmeth winchiligillo winchiligillo side ireland lieth neerer unto wale ordinarily usually every ebbe sea receiveth water flowing every return tide dischargeth voideth said water entertained sea ebbe hath going away tide forsaken creeke yet river runneth every chinke winding cranke becommeth bitter salt continuall brackishnesse toppe hill newcastle looketh sea seeth shelf sand call ground lying opposite great way lengththe ground howbeit betweene shore reported bee seven fathom deepe water little higher riveret bray commeth sea appeareth oldcourt possession walshes caryckmain ancient stocke gentryoldcourt family hath shot forth many ireland namely full forage unlesse cattell kept while grasing fulnesse would endanger much cattell feedeth within little circuit hath may reckon one time hundred twenty thousand head beast standeth achonry bishopricke united see elphin shannon soveraigne river ireland hath springhead one narrower another broader diver turning winding reach make washeth watereth either side said many country country farre wide dispersed rebel every way wood forrests yet received small foile overthrow cowardise served sir henry harrington punished severely martiall discipline neither returned latter end july souldiers wearied sickly number man would beleeve diminished upon returne understood queene displeased expedition costly yet damageable urged still journey ulster earle missive unto majesty transferred fault himselfe upon councell ireland unto manifold experience affaire ireland could choose condescend promising protesting faithfully set forward speed ulster scarce letter delivered dispatcheth others wherein signifieth upon necessity must turne journey aside ophaly neere dublin oconors omoils risen armes quickly fortunately vanquished light skirmish returning taken review army another way clifford forthwith putting himselfe journy power 1500 commanded souldiers outtoiled travelling farre small store gunpowder passe mountaines curlew gotten part rebel leading ororke assailed shalt honour delivered forth prison also came passe time arose contention betweene john king england king france seigniory certain castle suit controversie still depending king france offered unto giant champion fight right king england called remembrance valiant knight john curcie upon information others cast prison king therefore sent john curcie asked able help stand stead combat john answered said fight thee right kingdome afterward hee undertooke doe endeavour single fight refreshed himselfe meat drink bathing tooke vertue owne fortitude strength day appointed betweene giant champion namely betweene john curcie champion france heard exceeding great feeding strength hee refused combat said seigniorie given unto king england king france requested see stroake given hand john curcie set strong doughtie good morion full maile upon great blocke log wood foresaid john taking skeine sword looking back round stern grim countenance smote mo • ion crest downeward blocke sword item parliament holden london wherein little nothing done touching peace parliament king departed tooke journey france mandate king france king england many noble tooke badge crosse also lord john fitzthomas knighted nicolas fitzmaurice robert clonhull adare mounster last day may robert brus sent certaine gallies part ulster rover make spoile men ulster resisted manfully chased away said robert arrived licence earle take truce item summer master john decer citizen dublin caused necessarie bridge bee made without towne batiboght unto causey milpoole clontarf whereas time passenger way much endangered defraied great charge thereabout reason mightie inundation floud bridge arch fell downe also master john leek achbishop dublin feast st laurence ended mortall life schisme division side prince connaght okelley many prince potentate john husee butcher anry fought night request lord anry stood among dead seek discover okelley okelley costrell esquire rose lurking hole cried unto foresaid man wit husee come mee make thee great lord countrey husee answered goe thee thou shalt goe lord richard bermingham said okelley thou hast one servant thee doughtie esquire therefore come mee thou maist bee safe unto owne man also said agree goe away okelley wee may saved inriched stronger said john husee first killed owne servant okelley esquire cut three head carried lord richard
